name: Anarkul's Group

texts.en:
Anarkul B. is the leader of this group. She is thirty-three and married. She has two children of thirteen and eleven years old. Both of them go to school. Her husband is school teacher. Anarkul is also a school teacher. However, they also breed cattle. They started cattle breeding from a purchase of cattle with money that was obtained through sale of vegetables from their garden. They increased the number of cattle to seven. They started cattle breeding six years ago with an initial investment of 6000 soms. Anarkul applied for the loan to buy cattle in order to further increase their number. In the near future, they are planning to make capital repairs to their house with the profits from their business.  

Group members:

Sairagul M. is the treasurer of the group. She is thirty-two and married. She has three children: her son is fifteen and her daughters are twelve and six years old. All of them got to school. Her husband is a builder. Sairagul is a school teacher. Together with her husband, she started cattle breeding from a purchase of cattle with the first salary of her husband. Now, they have been almost four years in cattle breeding and they have significantly increased their herd. Now, they make at least 1000 soms each month on cattle breeding. They are applying for a loan in order to make capital repairs to their house before the winter period. In the future, with the profits from cattle breeding, they are planning to expand their herd as much as possible.

Nuriila R. is thirty-eight and married. She has four children. Her eldest child got married and lives independently. Her younger three children go to school and live with her. She is a teacher of Russian language and Literature at the local school. Her husband breeds cattle. They started cattle breeding with the help of a loan in the amount of 5000 soms. From that moment, they have significantly increased their herd. They have already been  in the cattle breeding business for seven years. They are applying for a loan in order to pay for their son’s education. 

Aidai Z. is thirty-nine and a widow. She has three children. Her elderst child got married and lives independently. Her younger children live with her. They go to school. She is a teacher at the local school. She combines her job as a teacher with cattle breeding. She started cattle breeding fifteen years ago with her husband using money from his salary in the amount of 3000 soms. Now, she is applying for a loan in order to buy cattle for fattening. In the future, she is planning to build a house and buy a car for her family. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

use: to purchase cattle

name: Anonymous
use: buy a motorbike for family use

name: Anonymous
use: buy pigs to raise

name: Phan

texts.en: Phan S., 26, is married and resides with her husband and their young child in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. S. and her husband are employed at a local garment factory, earning an income of USD 3.30 each per day. S. is requesting a loan of USD 300 to build a new house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. S.'s husband appears in the photograph because S. was not available.

use: build a new house

name: Mao

texts.en: Mao D., 47, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia.  This area is known for its quality palm products. D. sells shoes to earn an income of USD 10 per day. Her husband is employed at a magazine company, earning an income of USD 2 per day. D. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase more shoes to sell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

use: buy more shoes to resell

name: San

texts.en: Mr. San S. is a villager who lives in Phnom Penh, where the people are able to run their businesses well. San S. is married and has two kids, who are no longer in school, but are employed in the garment factories. To pursue a daily income, San S. owns a kiosk inside the market where he sells chickens to citizens who come to buy something for their cooking. He and his wife always travel to the rural areas in order to buy chickens, then slaughter them at their house. The couple has been engaged in this job since early 2005. Presently, San S. has a motorcycle that is not able to carry all of his items. He hopes to have a trailer that he will use to pick up more chickens. This is why San S. decided to borrow a loan for the purpose of buying a trailer.

use: To buy a trailer.

name: En

texts.en: En T., 48, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia.  This area is known for its quality palm products. T. is a farmer and earns USD 1 per day. Her husband buys cows to resell, earning USD 4 per day. T. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase a pump to help improve farming. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

use: buy a water pump

name: Toch

texts.en: Toch D., 33, is widowed and resides with two children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia.  This area is known for its quality palm products. D. is a cleaner at the factory and earns an income of USD 1.6 per day. One of her daughter is a worker at the garment factory, earning an income of USD 1.3 per day. D. is requesting a loan of USD 300 to repair her house.  This is her fifth loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

use: repair her house

name: Kon Tol

texts.en:
Kon Tol B. lives in Kaoh Reah Leu village, Kandal province.  She was born in 1983.  Kon Tol and her husband are farmers who rent a plot of land to grow papaya and mango to sell to support their family.   Her husband is also a horse cart driver. 

Her problem is that her mango field has a lot of insects. To improve production, Kon Tol is asking for a loan to buy pesticides. She is the mother of two children who are too young to work or study.

use: Buy pesticides.

name: Chhun

texts.en: Chhun S., 41, is married and resides with her husband and five children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. S. and her husband are employed at a local garment factory for an income of USD 3.3 each per day. S. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase a motorbike for family use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

use: To buy a motorbike for family use.

name: Pen

texts.en: Pen P., 42, is married and resides with her husband and a child in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. P. is a farmer and earns an income of USD 2.5 per day. Her husband produces rice wine, earning an income of USD 3 per day. P. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase more rice to produce rice wine product. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. P. appears in the photograph with her husband while she is helping her husband to produce rice wine.

use: To buy rice to produce rice wine product.

name: Chy

texts.en:
Chy S. is a hard-working man who has spent his life cultivating crops.  He has pieces of farm fields in which to grow various vegetables. 

Three months after planting he harvests his crops and sells them at the market.  Chy is the father of six children, one of whom is employed and the others go to school.  Chy has had great success growing vegetable.  He is able to plant crops at least twice a year. 

Chy will be used this loan to purchase fertilizer, insecticide, a pump and seeds for planting.

use: Purchasing fertilizer, insecticide, a pump and seeds for planting.

name: Melanie

texts.en:
Melanie B., age 45, and her husband Eliseo, have four children, one in high school, one in college, and two in elementary school. Melanie works hard to cover daily expenses and her children's education, and for the past five years has been selling fashion bags, electronic items,  and frozen food door-to-door to generate income. 

Melanie is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan to help her purchase additional inventory for sale. The loans allow her to buy in bulk when prices are cheapest, and she hopes that the additional inventory will allow her to attract more customers.

Melanie has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for several loan cycles and has consistently attended weekly fellowship meetings.* She hopes that earnings from her business will be sufficient to cover her children's education costs through graduation.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

use: To purchase more inventory.

name: Seiylkan's Group

texts.en:
Seiylkan S. is the leader of the group. She is 47 and married. She has raised three sons and two daughters; her two older sons and first daughter study at university and the other children are at school. Seiylkan is engaged in cattle breeding and her husband works as a taxi driver; when he is free he helps his wife with her work. Seiylkan started to breed cattle two years ago with an initial investment of 15,000 soms. With that money she purchased two bulls and resold them at a higher price (23,000 soms) after fattening them. With money received from the loan, Seiylkan wants to purchase farm animals to increase the number of cattle. In the future she wants to improve her living conditions and give her children a good education.

Gulbaira K., 48, is married. She has a son and a daughter; the son is a private entrepreneur and the daughter is of preschool age (under 7). Gulbaira and her husband are engaged in cattle breeding; they started this activity two years ago with an initial investment of 20,000 soms. They bought a cow and then after a month that cow was resold at the higher price (30,000 soms). With money received from the loan, Gulbaira wants to purchase cattle for breeding and some part of the loan she will spend to purchase hay.

Guljan I., 54, is married. Her husband works as a teacher at school and Guljan is engaged in livestock breeding. She applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase farm animals in order to increase the number of livestock. In the future she wants to improve her living conditions.

Roza M. is the treasurer of the group.  She is 45 and married. She has two sons and a daughter; the first son studies at university, the second is at school and the daughter is of preschool age (under 7). Roza is engaged in cattle breeding and her husband works as an electrician. In 2009, Roza bought a bull for 8,000 soms and then, after fattening it, resold it for 11,000 soms. And since then she has been breeding cattle. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase farm animals in order to increase the number of cattle. In the future, she wants to expand her business activity and provide her children with a good education.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan.

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

use: To purchase farm animals.

name: Halima

texts.en: Halima is a divorced woman with two boys who all attend school. She has been operating her retail shop for the last six years, selling in a shop to her neighbors and passersby. With the KSH 40,000 she wants to purchase maize flour, wheat flour and cooking oil. Her previous occupation was a restaurant operator. Halima faces the major challenge of creditors taking too long to pay back, hence low realization of profits. She hopes to open a bigger shop in future and sell more stock. Her main aim of working with Yehu is to expand her business. She rents a house with electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

use: To purchase maize flour, wheat flour and cooking oil.

name: Elzevir

texts.en:
When Elzevir became a member of Kiva's field partner Ahon Sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI), she found that she not only received capital from them, but also her second family in the presence of co-members. That is why she enjoys being a part of it. Now, her 3rd loan will be used as additional capital for her sari-sari (variety) store. She will buy different groceries and many other items that are needed for her business.

Elzevir says she is working hard, not only to have a better life for herself, but also to help her parents and her niece in their needs. She is just hoping to have a long life so that she can do this. Elzevir is hoping that, with ASHI's and Kiva's support, there is a big possibility that the family can fulfill its dreams.

Elzevir’s business has been very helpful in achieving her family's dreams. Her greatest hope is that her family will be able to have a good life, as it currently lives in poverty. Her long term goals are to invest and build a better house for the family and to have a full-fledged mini-grocery store.

use: To buy groceries and many other items that are needed for her store

name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma B. is from the village of San Juan. She is 40 years old and married. Gemma owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Gemma is just starting this business.

In 2009, Gemma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gemma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Gemma is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Gemma from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

use: to purchase additional products to sell

name: Rodolfo

texts.en:
Rodolfo P. is from the village of Sta. Isabel Norte. He is 47 years old, married and has 7 school-aged children. Rodolfo owns and operates a farming business, planting and harvesting rice for sale. Rodolfo has been engaged in his business for over 20 years and earns approximately 20,000 PHP during harvest season.

In 2010, Rodolfo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rodolfo is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Rodolfo from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise

name: Amelita

texts.en:
Amelita L. is from the village of San Juan. She is 47 years old, married and has 2 adult-aged children. Amelita owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Amelita has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2009, Amelita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Amelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Amelita is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Amelita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

use: to purchase additional products to sell

name: Alnie

texts.en:
Alnie F. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 47 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. Alnie owns and operates a farming business, planting and harvesting rice for sale. Alnie has been engaged in her business for over 25 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month from it.

Alnie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alnie has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Alnie from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business and supplement the family's income. Alnie wishes for CEVI to continue to expand so more farmers could avail of its programs.

use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies

name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is a 48-year-old gentleman married to Esther. They have eight children, who all go to school. 

Peter was introduced to Kadet by existing members and this will be his second loan. He plans to purchase additional cattle for resale at a profit. Peter has been in the cattle-selling business for the last 20 years and likes the business since he makes good profit from it.

His future plan is to expand his business and move to other towns to sell his cattle, hence making more profit to sustain his family.

use: To buy cattle for resale

name: Antonio

texts.en: Antonio S. is from the village of General Balao, Solana, Cagayan. He is 32 years old. Antonio is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Antonio provides painting services to local community members. Antonio has been engaged in his business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. Antonio joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Antonio is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the first loan taken out by Antonio from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of his family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

use: To invest in expanding the business

name: Caroline

texts.en:
Caroline is married to Mr. Keino and they have been blessed with two children, aged 8 and 2.5 years old. She runs a business of selling fruits and vegetables like mangoes, bananas, oranges, tomatoes and onions. She has been in the business for six years and she says that it is able to meet all her needs.

Caroline is now applying for her second loan, which she plans to use to purchase additional fruits and vegetables to ensure continued supply to her esteemed customers, whom she says are satisfied with her services.

She plans to buy a plot in the future and develop buildings for renting so that she can earn additional income.

use: To purchase additional fruits and vegetables
